Science Instruction in Early Childhood: Too Soon or Just Right?
Science Instruction in Early Childhood: Too Soon or Just Right?

NRC, 2007, “Taking Science to School”
NRC, 2007, “Taking Science to School”

• A major component of this report documented the importance of the preschool period for introducing science and the need to capitalize on cognitive research on how young children learn.

• “We are underestimating what young children are capable of as students of science – the bar is almost always set too low … science education as currently structured does not leverage the knowledge and capabilities students bring to the classroom. For students from diverse backgrounds, the problem is even more profound.”

Need for Better Assessment of Early Science
Need for Better Assessment of Early Science

• Measures of preschool science that are not directly tied to a specific curriculum are needed to evaluate science-based curricula and interventions, but currently there are none available.
• Measures of preschool science that are not directly tied to a • M e a s u r e s
o f
p r e s c h o o l
s c i e n c e
t h a t
a r e
n o t
d i r e c t l y
t i e d
t o
a
specific curriculum are needed to evaluate science-based
curricula and interventions, but currently there are none
available.

In response to this need, our team developed a reliable and valid Item Response Theory (IRT)-based direct assessment of preschool science using the guidelines for measurement development from the Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing (AERA, APA, & NCME, 1999).
In response to this need, our team developed a reliable and valid
Item Response Theory (IRT)-based direct assessment of
preschool science using the guidelines for measurement
development from the Standards for Educational and
Psychological Testing (AERA, APA, & NCME, 1999).
